bboxes.raw_text:
TUCSON The citys civil
rights ordinance became eff
fective this week and 1t covers
discrimination in places Of public
accommodation.


The National Association for
the Advancement of Colored
People and the Congress of Racial
Equality have no plans to test the
ordinance. Both groups are
critical of 1t.


CORE president Roy Twitty
said his group is interested pri-
marily in a voter registration
drive and there we're no plans
to test a motel or restaurant.


Casper Glenn, minister and
president of the local NAACP
Chapter summarized the or
dinance as weak, although itpro-
vides some local avenues of
action.

TUesOn's Civil Rights
Law Is Effective

he says, 81 didn't see how |
could honestly preach the Gospel
of Christ in church that
practiced discrimination
But | never abandoned His
teaching.


From l94I to l945 he served
as race relations secretary Of the
Fellowship of Reconciliation.
From 1916 to 1913 he took part
in the organizing drive in the
South Of the Upholsterers' In
ternational Union. Later he
served as international repre-
sentative Of the State, County and
Municipal Employees Union, and
in 1858 he was designated one Of
a five man delegation from the
International Confederation Of
Free Trade Unions to fifteen
African countries. farmer also
served as a Program Director
for NAACP and was COM
mentator on radio and television.


In 1912, with group of students
at the University of Chicago,
Farmer organized the first chap
ter of CORE. The group intended,
in his words, Ito substitute
bodies for exhortations" and
to apply to the struggle for racial
equality in the United States the
techniques of nonviolence and
passive resistance that Gandhi
used SO successfully in India's
struggle for independence.


AS National Director ofCORE,
Farmer not only plans projects
but also participates in carrying
many of them out. He was one
of the original Freedom Riders,
and, like most of the group. he
spent forty days in Jail in 1901.
He was next impris oned in August
1868, for leading a civil rights
demonstration in Plaquemine,
Louisiana. On April y, 1864
he and 800 other CORE members
we're arrested in New York while
protesting segregation and dis
elimination practiced by many
states exhibiting at the Worlds
Fair.

John Robert Lewis Is the only
leader Of a civil rights organiza-
ton elected by civil rights
activists.


Lewis a "a year old ALBANIAN
Is the son of laundress, and a
farmer.


He attended the public schools
Of Troy and Pike County. and
was graduated from the Ameri-
can Baptist Seminary in Nash
Vile, Tennessee with an BA de-
gree in religion in 1861. He
has continued studies toward an
BA degree in philos ophy at Fish
University.


Lewis has been arrested 81
times. He was an organizer of
the Nashville Student Movement
and an original Freedom Rider.
He was instrumental in continuing
the rides after othe civil rights
groups withdrew their support
contending the rides we're too
dangerous" He suffered
beating from mob when his
bus arrived at Montgomery. Ala
bama on Mothers Day, 1861.


Since assuming SNCC's chair
manship, Lewis has visited and
participated in SNCC projects in
Mississippi, Arkansas, Georgia
and Alabama.


He was once of leaders at the
August 1868 March on Washing
ton. His speech at that time
kicked offSNCC's widespreadus
of the African slogan, Zone Man
One Vote,'' which describes
SNCC's Southwide program
aimed at removing all barriers
to the vote except age and resi-
dence.

James Farmer was one Of the
group that founded Congress Of
Racial Equality (CORE) In 1912.
He was its first National Chair
man and became Its National d.
rector in 1861. In the spring
of 1861, he led CORES first
Freedom Ride: as result. he was
held in Mississippi iails for more
than a month. Farmer has also
worked for the Fellowship of Re-
Cancellation, the NAACP, and
several labor unions.


James Farmer was born In
Marshall, Texas on January IL,
1920, the son of scholar and
the grandson of a slave. He
earned his BIS. degree in
chemistry from Wiley College
when he was only eighteen years
old. He enrolled in the School of
Religion of Howard University,
Washington, DC, to prepare
for the Methodist ministry. AS
a student he was active in the
Christian Youth Movement,
serving as Vice Chairman of the
National Council of Methodist
Youth and the Christian Youth
Council of North america. Far
mer received the degree of
Bachelor of Divinity in l94l,
but declined ordination. Re-
calling that the Methodist Church
in the South was then segregated,

About 2.7 million are employed
in science and technology in the
u. ST. About half a million per-
sons are working as scientists,
nearly million as engineers, a
million as technicians, and
quarter of million as teachers
of science and mathematics in
secondary schools.

will be added and SIS old patrol
cars will be replaced.


He stated that the officers
patrol more than E million miles
and answer 100000 calls
annually.


The increased police Depart
ment budget this year will pro-
vide $4,000 for merit pay raises
for patrolmen every six months.

Mayor Milton Graham an
nounced that II additional police
men and four civilians will be
employed by the city police de-
partment by Jan. l..


This will increase the force
to 824 including more than 100
civilian employees.


Graham said that the mobile
radio communications system
will be impr owed, more vehicles
